iwork.patchpanel
Class MappingMan

java.lang.Object
  iwork.patchpanel.MappingMan
All Implemented Interfaces:
VariableResolver
public class MappingMan
extends java.lang.Object
implements VariableResolver

This Mapping Manager class serves to abstract the implementation of the translation map from other applications that use it.

Translation Mapping Overview:

To create a translation mapping, one needs to specify a translation criteria and an event list for translation output. The translation criteria provides the minimum set of field names and values that an incoming event or translation candidate must have for the translation to occur. A translation candidate can satisfy multiple translation criteria. In this case the translation output would contain the combined output of all mappings triggered.

Implementation:

The translation map is structured as a hierarchical set of hash tables. By using hash tables we are able to place translation mappings using hash keys that are formed by concatenating field values. The concatenation strategy effectively results in simultaneously comparing all necessary field values for equality in a single operation.

The field value hash tables are the leaves of our hash table tree. It's parent hash table is a field name hash table. By storing the field name hash table, we can quickly update the table when a new mapping is specified. These two hash tables are sufficient for storing all translation mappings.

When a new incoming event or translation candidate arrives, the candidate could theoretically satisfy any mapping in the tree. The Mapping Manager must traverse the entire set of field name combinations. These different field name combinations correspond to the fields included in the translation criteria specification. For each entry, a concatenated field value hash key is composed and tested. If the entry exists the output events are appended to the total list of output events.

The flaw in this structure is that as the number of different types of mappings increases, the list traversal can get expensive. To mitigate this expense, we have included one more level of hierarchy based on EventType. This reduces the number of mappings for traversal to the subset of mappings that have the same EventType as part of there translation criteria. The drawback of this solution is that we have restricted the flexibility of the mapping specification. A translation cannot be specified that is independent of EventType. One would have to create a mapping for each event type to effectively achieve an EventType blind translation. At this time we feel this is an acceptable tradeoff.

In summary the hash table tree hierarchy is structured as follows

root: EventTypeHash key: EventType

level 1: FieldNameHash key: concatenated string of field names

level 2: FieldNameEntryHash key: { FieldNameList, FieldValueHash }

level 2: FieldNameList - this is present so the field value hash key can be constructed

level 3: FieldValueHash key: concateanted string of field values

level 4: TranslationHash key: { transCriteria, eventList }

Constructor Detail

MappingMan

public MappingMan(Intermediary intermediary)
This is the constructor for the Mapping Manager.

NOTE: There should only be one instance of the Mapping Manager per event heap. The Patch Panel Intermediary should own that instance and other process modify mappings through it

translate

public iwork.eheap2.Event[] translate(iwork.eheap2.Event eventToMap)
This function performs an event translation based on the incoming event. The incoming event is a translation candidate that must satisfy at least one translation criteria for the resulting array to be non-empty. This function also evaluates any specified field value equations.

Parameters:
eventToMap - the translation candidate to evaluate mappings for.
Returns:
an array representing the translation output based on current translation specification

getTranslation

public iwork.eheap2.Event[] getTranslation(iwork.eheap2.Event eventToMap)
This function performs an event translation based on the incoming event. The incoming event is a translation candidate that must satisfy at least one translation criteria for the resulting array to be non-empty. This function does not evaluate any field value equations. This is the only difference between this function and translate()

Parameters:
eventToMap - the translation candidate to evaluate mappings for.
Returns:
an array representing the translation output based on current translation specification

public java.lang.String getAllGlobalVariables()
Returns a string representing the names and values of all global variables, in the following tab-delimited format: varGroup1 (tab) varName1 (tab) varType1 (tab) varValue1 (tab) varName2 (tab) etc.

setMapping

public int setMapping(java.lang.String mappingString)
Specify a new translation mapping for the supplied translation criteria. When a subsequent translation candidate meets this particular translation criteria, the events specified in the eventList will be apart of the translation output.

Parameters:
mappingString - string representing a full translation mapping including both translation criteria and intended translation output
Returns:
0 on success. -1 on failure

resolve

public java.lang.Object resolve(java.lang.String s,
                                int callCount)
This function takes a equation string and replaces any variables contained within it. All field names should be predicated with "in." or "out." to indicate which event to find the field. If no predicate is found, "in." is implied. Field names predicated with "global." indicate that the value should be found in the table of patch panel variables. These variables can be added and changed by sending setGlobalVariable events to the patch panel.

Specified by:
resolve in interface VariableResolver
Returns:
a string containing the expression without variables

main

public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
A test case interface for this class.
